questions.stem: Is there an absolute right to full pre-interview disclosure?

options.text: Yes — police must disclose everything
No — while disclosure should be sufficient to allow advice, there is no absolute right to full disclosure before interview
Only for summary offences
Only if the solicitor demands it

questions.explanation: Case law (notably R v Farrell) clarified that while disclosure should be sufficient for advice, there is no absolute right to full pre-interview disclosure.

references.cite: PACE 1984 s.56 (right to have someone informed)

questions.stem: When might a prepared statement be particularly useful?

options.text: When the client wants to answer all questions freely
When disclosure is limited and you want to put a defence on record while avoiding speculation under questioning
When the client has nothing to say
Never — prepared statements are inadmissible

questions.explanation: A prepared statement allows key points to be raised (reducing adverse inference risk) while avoiding the dangers of answering questions based on limited information.

questions.stem: Police disclose a witness statement summary but not the full statement. What should you do?

options.text: Assume the summary is complete
Ask clarifying questions about what the witness actually said and note any limitations for the record
Refuse to continue until you have the full statement
Ignore the witness evidence entirely

questions.explanation: Summaries may omit important detail. Ask targeted questions to understand the allegation, note limitations, and advise accordingly.

questions.stem: What is the main risk of a blanket 'no comment' approach?

options.text: It's illegal
It may allow adverse inferences if facts later relied upon at trial could reasonably have been mentioned in interview
It guarantees conviction
There is no risk

questions.explanation: Under CJPOA s.34, adverse inferences may be drawn from silence if facts later relied upon could reasonably have been mentioned earlier. This makes blanket no comment risky.

references.cite: Criminal Justice and Public Order Act 1994 s.34 (inference from silence)

questions.stem: How should you record disclosure limitations in your notes?

options.text: Don't record them — it's oral only
Note what was requested, what was provided, what was withheld/unclear, and the impact on advice
Only record if police sign your notes
Wait until after interview

questions.explanation: Clear notes on disclosure (or lack thereof) support your advice and provide a record for later fairness arguments if needed.

questions.stem: Your client wants to give a partial account — some questions answered, others no comment. What is the key advice?

options.text: This is always inadvisable
Ensure the approach is consistent and can be explained; document the strategy and reasons
Randomly choose which to answer
Let police decide which questions to skip

questions.explanation: A mixed approach can work but must be logical and defensible. Document the strategy so it's clear why certain topics were addressed and others weren't.

questions.stem: What should you ask for at minimum before interview?

options.text: The officer's personal opinion on the case
The nature of the allegation, the key evidence relied upon, and what the interview will cover
A full copy of the police file
Nothing — just wait for the interview

questions.explanation: At minimum, you need to understand what is alleged and the evidence basis. This allows meaningful advice even if full disclosure isn't available.

questions.stem: How does inadequate disclosure affect adverse inference risk?

options.text: It has no effect
It may provide a reasonable explanation for not mentioning facts — disclosure limitations can support fairness arguments
It increases adverse inference risk
It automatically prevents any inference

questions.explanation: Documented disclosure limitations can support an argument that it was reasonable not to mention certain facts. Recording is key.

questions.stem: Police say there is CCTV but won't describe what it shows. How should you proceed?

options.text: Assume it proves the allegation
Ask for a summary of what the CCTV is said to show; note the refusal if they won't provide one
Tell the client to confess
Ignore the CCTV

questions.explanation: Without knowing what evidence shows, advice is difficult. Ask for a summary and record the response. If refused, note this for strategy and potential fairness arguments.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of asking the police what offence is alleged?

options.text: To show off your legal knowledge
To understand what conduct is in issue so you can advise on elements, defences, and strategy
To delay the interview
It's not important

questions.explanation: Knowing the offence helps you understand what needs to be proved, what defences apply, and how to approach the interview.

questions.stem: If police provide only verbal disclosure, what should you do?

options.text: Rely entirely on memory
Make detailed notes of what was said and clarify any unclear points
Refuse to proceed without written disclosure
Ask the client to remember for you

questions.explanation: Verbal disclosure is common. Take careful notes, ask clarifying questions, and ensure you have a clear record of what was and wasn't disclosed.

questions.stem: Your client's account differs from what police have disclosed. What is the professional approach?

options.text: Assume the client is lying
Explore the discrepancy, consider the evidence quality, and advise on strategy including risks of each approach
Tell the client to change their account to match police
Disclose the discrepancy to police before interview

questions.explanation: Discrepancies are common. Explore the facts with the client, assess the strength of evidence, and advise on risks. Don't assume either version is correct.
